qas.question: Which ideas had little criticism for the most part?
What is the term for how the church as a whole works?
What group believes that some in the church have a special status to understand the bible?
At what period was inerrancy debated?
What item could be learned to gain salvation?

context: The <a0_0>necessity and inerrancy<a0_0/> were well-established ideas, garnering little criticism, though they later came under debate from outside during <a3_0>the Enlightenment<a3_0/>. The most contentious idea at the time though was the notion that anyone could simply pick up <a4_0>the Bible<a4_0/> and learn enough to gain salvation. Though the reformers were concerned with <a1_0>ecclesiology<a1_0/> (the doctrine of how the church as a body works), they had a different understanding of the process in which truths in scripture were applied to life of believers, compared to the <a2_0>Catholics<a2_0/>' idea that certain people within the church, or ideas that were old enough, had a special status in giving understanding of the text.
